bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wade H. Frost, March 29, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] comments on Snow's living organism theory of disease.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wade H. Frost, March 29, 1922
div1.opener:
Miss.
Lecture
Frost
Book
Nott
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
March 29, 1922.
/LC
Dear Doctor Frost:
div1.p: I am returning your Excerpts from Snow.

I judge Sir Henry Holland is the immediate cause of Snow and
Nott, and doubtless others, taking up the living organism idea of
disease. In Nott's case he was reproached for “going back to the ani-
malism of savage and barbarous people”--his animalculi replacing their
evil spirits: All three were fore-runners of the “germ theory.”

Of them all Snow is the most logical and safest, because he is
more indefinite as to details--making no analogy that his two basic
facts do not substantiate. Wise is he too to substitute “communicable”
for “contagious.” Had LeRoche done this--I have just “waded” through
his voluminous work--he would not have been as utterly mistaken as he
was--as illogical--and, I hope, had written not more than 1/4 as much!
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General.
